heading: amazon.com wows analysts
subheading: amazon beats wall street's first-quarter projections with a whopping 236 percent increase in revenues. losses triple, however.
author: reuters
text: internet retailing giant amazon.com inc. beat wall street expectations on wednesday by reporting first-quarter revenue growth of 236 percent and smaller losses than analysts expected. amazon.com (amzn) said it suffered a pro forma net loss of us$36.4 million, or 23 cents per share in the quarter, compared with a net loss of $10.4 million, or 7 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1998. revenues rose to $294 million from $87 million a year earlier.on average, analysts had expected a loss of 29 cents a share, according to first call.as expected, revenues also exceeded the $253 million reported by amazon.com in the seasonally strong december quarter and exceeded the estimates of analysts who expected revenues in the $260-million-to-$270-million range.the results were "well in excess of my expectations," said derek brown, analyst at volpe, brown, whelan & co., calling the results "a phenomenal quarter, as q1 is traditionally a seasonally slow period of time for retailers.""after a strong first quarter we didn't think that they could improve that much, but they've shown a 35 percent revenue growth sequentially over the last quarter in what should be a seasonally slow time of year," said lauren levitan, analyst at bancboston robertson stephens. "it shows that these guys are synonymous with online shopping."including $25.3 million in costs stemming from acquisitions, amazon.com lost $61.7 million, or 39 cents per share, in the quarter. amazon.com bought controlling stakes in drugstore.com and pets.com in the latest quarter, part of the company's aggressive plan to maintain a dominant position in internet retailing through acquisitions.in a statement, amazon.com founder and ceo jeff bezos said the company was particularly pleased with its new auction service, launched in late march. he said that the auctions feature had more participants in its first month than the company's music offering did in its first month last year.amazon.com, which sells books, videos, music, and gifts from its web site, said it added 2.2 million customers in the quarter for a total of 8.4 million. more than 66 percent of orders in the quarter came from repeat customers, the company said."the number that is incredibly impressive is the 8.4 million total customers -- that is incredibly impressive," said levitan. "these are phenomenal results, and it seems everybody getting online is going to amazon."the results were issued after the close of nasdaq trading, at which point amazon had fallen $13 to close at $192.88 a share. in after-hours trading, the stock slipped further to $185.75, traders said.copyright
